text.pdl__result: The fastest animal on land is the cheetah. This incredible creature can reach speeds up to 60-70 miles per hour (97-113 kilometers per hour) in short bursts covering distances of about 1,500 feet (460 meters). Cheetahs have several adaptations that contribute to their incredible speed, including a lean body, long legs, and a unique, flexible spine. They also have large lungs for efficient oxygen intake during high-speed chases.

context.content: The fastest animal on land is the cheetah. This incredible creature can reach speeds up to 60-70 miles per hour (97-113 kilometers per hour) in short bursts covering distances of about 1,500 feet (460 meters). Cheetahs have several adaptations that contribute to their incredible speed, including a lean body, long legs, and a unique, flexible spine. They also have large lungs for efficient oxygen intake during high-speed chases.

text.pdl__result:
In Europe, the fastest land animal is still the cheetah, as it does not inhabit this continent naturally due to its preference for open savannas and grasslands. However, if we consider European hares (Lepus europaeus), they are the fastest terrestrial mammals native to Europe. Hares can reach speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour (31 miles per hour) in short bursts over distances of about 200-400 meters, thanks to their powerful hind legs and long, muscular bodies.

For aquatic animals, the European sturgeon is one of the fastest, reaching speeds up to 35 kilometers per hour (22 miles per hour) in short bursts while swimming. This species is known for its long, powerful body and large, flat head, which helps it navigate through water efficiently.

In summary, cheetahs are the fastest land animals globally, but if we limit our discussion to Europe, hares become the fastest terrestrial mammals, while European sturgeons hold the title for the fastest aquatic animal in this region.
